Situation1: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: A weekend stroll through the park passes posted no-littering signs and a nearby trash bin.
Story: I was still wearing my work uniform, the name tag heavy on my chest, when I left the store after a long shift. My mind replayed the scene from earlier: a customer, red-faced and loud, berating me over a coupon that wouldn’t scan. I’d smiled, apologized, and kept my voice calm, even as my heart pounded. That’s what was expected—be patient, be friendly, no matter what. Now, walking through the park, I tried to shake off the tension. The air was cool, the grass dotted with families. I unwrapped a granola bar, the wrapper crinkling in my hand. I spotted the trash bin a few steps away, but I was tired, my feet aching. For a moment, I considered dropping the wrapper on the ground, just this once. But the no-littering sign glared at me, reminding me of my responsibility as a citizen to respect public spaces. The weight of both roles pressed on me—one demanding endless patience, the other expecting me to do the right thing, even when no one was watching. I stood there, torn, the wrapper in my hand, caught between what was easy and what was right.
